Last winter I left a bottle of water in my car when I went into work.  At the end of the day I came out, and there it was, still liquid water. I picked it up, and took the top off, and it was still liquid water.  Then I went to take a drink, and all I got was a few drops of water and a bunch of ice. I had tried to do the whole supercooled water thing before, but it never worked for me. I thought it was so amazing (avoiding the cool joke here).  But I was a little bummed that I didn't have any water to drink.

I'm not sure the last question is correct. As Hank himself referenced in his song 'Strange Charm', pulling two quarks away from each other causes two new quarks to be generated and pair with the original quarks. This would seem to me to be quantum particles spontaneously duplicating, as in answer D...

Maybe this doesn't meet the definition of 'spontaneous', but given their definition of time running backwards I don't think it's too much of a stretch.

Amazing show guys- If I could ask one thing: Instead of saying "scientists", especially when discussing research, it would be great if you said " Behavioral Ecologists from the University of whatever" or "Evolutionary Biologists at this institute". Not only would we learn lots of different names for professions and centers of study, but STEM students like myself would benefit from hearing about specific research going on in many different fields and hearing about research institutions to look out for when perusing journals. Keep up the good work!

On a quantum scale, that is sort of incorrect Hank.
Just moments before you said that "Matter can not be created", One of the theories of The Quantum was that "Particles (spontaneously) pop in and out of existence" which, at the very least, should lead to a qualitative addition to your statement.

And considering one of the contemporary theories of how our known universe exists is that these spontaneous particles popped into existence and collided with enough force to create a quantum explosion, which lead to more matter than anti-matter being created and expansion to occur... again... there is a lot of qualitative explanation that is required to lean on "Matter can not be created".
It falls in to the same category of "you can't divide by zero". We may not understand "how", yet, but there is evidence to support that it can / does happen, albeit improbable on even a cosmic scale.

Technically the particle duplicating answer isn‘t entirely wrong. It‘s assumed that duplication as in the creation of two entirely equal particle from one particle isn‘t possible but there are theories about two opposite particles being created out of nothing. For example, Hawking Radiation (radiation from a black hole) is explained by particles popping into existence close to a black hole‘s event horizon. Because anything travelling at speeds equal to or below light speed cannot escape the event horizon one particle gets pulled into the black hole while the other escapes.

So with entropy, isn’t disorder just a tendency, not a hard and fast rule? Prof. Moriarty explained it on one of Brady Haran’s channels as disorder basically just being an option, and while the most likely one, not necessarily always the one you’ll get. So with a system going from disordered to ordered, I think calling it time traveling in reverse is misleading. That’s also just entropy.
